metadata.title: Evaluation of the cytotoxic potential of extracts from the genus Passiflora 2 cultived in Brazil against cancer cells

abstract.text: 20 This work aimed to evaluate the cytotoxic potential against cancer cells of Passiflora genus 21 plant species cultivated in Brazil and identify the mechanism of cytotoxicity induced by the 22 most promising extract. Leaf extracts from 14 Passiflora (P.) species were obtained ASE and 23 in vitro cytotoxicity evaluated against cancer cell lines using MTT assay at a single . CC-BY 4.0 International license author/funder. It is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/337253 doi: bioRxiv preprint 2 24 concentration of 50 μg/mL. Additionally, the IC 50 of the P. alata (ELPA) leaf extracts was 25 determined against both tumor (HCT-116, SF-295, OVACAR-8, and HL-60), and non-tumor 26 cells (PBMC). The ELPA flavonoids were identified by HPLC-DAD and UHPLC-MS/MS. 27 The morphological analyses used light and fluorescence microscopy, and cell cycle and DNA 28 fragmentation analyses used flow cytometry to determine the mechanism of cell death induced 29 by ELPA in HL-60. Among the Passiflora leaf extracts evaluated; ELPA stood out with high 30 cytotoxic activity, followed by P. capsularis and P. quadrangulares with varying high and low 31 cytotoxic activity. ELPA presented high cytotoxic potency in HL-60 (IC 50 19.37 μg/mL), yet 32 without cytotoxic activity against PBMC, suggesting selectivity for tumor cells. The cytotoxic 33 activity of ELPA may well be linked to the presence of ten identified flavonoids. Cells treated 34 with ELPA presented the hallmarks typical of apoptosis and necrosis, with cell cycle arrest in 35 the G2/M phase. Conclusion: From among the studied species, ELPA presented greater 36 cytotoxic activity, possibly a consequence of synergistic flavonoid action which induces cell 37 death by apoptosis and necrosis.

166 After incubation, the formazan product was dissolved in 150 μL DMSO, and absorbance was 167 measured using a multi-plate reader (DTX 880 Multimode Detector, Beckman Coulter Inc. (Table   241 1 ). The results were analyzed for each cell line tested using a GI% scale as follows: samples 242 with low cytotoxic activity have GI < 50%; samples with moderate cytotoxic activity have GI 243 between 50% and 75%, and samples with high cytotoxic activity have GI > 75% (25). The 244 results showed that the extracts of P. cincinnata (3), P. gibertii (4), P. maliforms (5), P.
245 mallacophyla (6), P. murchronata (7), P. morifolia (8) P. racemosa (10), P. setacea (11), P.

. CC-BY 4.0 International license author/funder. It is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/337253 doi: bioRxiv preprint 246 suberosa (12), P. tenuifila (13) and P. vitifolia (14) have low or nonexistent cytotoxic activity 247 in all human cancer cell lines tested. Extracts from P. capsularis (2) and P. quadrangulares (9) 248 have high activity against HCT-116, low activity against SF-295, and cytotoxic activity from 249 low (P. quadrangulares) to moderate (P. capsularis) against OVACAR-8. The extract from 250 the leaves of P. alata (1) presented high cytotoxic activity in all human cancer cell lines 251 analyzed. Therefore, among the Passiflora leaf extracts evaluated P. alata (1) stands out with 252 promising cytotoxic activity, followed by P. capsularis (2) and P. quadrangulares (9). (Table 2) .

The cytotoxic activity of natural bioactive products against cancer cells is attributed to 295 the chemical composition of the product, and this practice of identification is the most 296 successful source of potential drug discovery and development (7).

FIGREF0.text: a sample of about 3 mL of human blood plus 5 mL of saline. The steps up to 149 isolation included the addition of 3 mL of Ficoll followed by 15 minutes of centrifugation at 150 1500 rpm, and aspiration of the PBMCs present in the intermediate region between the red 151 blood cells and the plasma. The PBMC suspension was transferred to another tube which was 152 added with saline to the 11 mL volume and centrifuged for 5 minutes at 1000 rpm. The 153 supernatant was discarded, and the PBMC pellet was re-suspended in complete medium (RPMI 154 1640 plus 20% fetal bovine serum and 10 μg/mL ConA) and counted in a Neubauer chamber 155 for further dilution and plating. 156 157 Determination of the cytotoxic effect of Passiflora extracts on cancer cell lines 158 The MTT assay was used to determine the cytotoxic effect of the 14 extracts of 159 Passiflora leaves against tumor cell lines (20). For all experiments, HCT-116 cells (0,7 x 10 5 160 cells/mL in 100 µL medium), SF-295 and OVCAR-8 cells (0.1 × 10 6 cells/mL in 100 µL 161 medium) were seeded in 96-well plates and incubated in a humidified chamber with 5% CO 2 162 at 37°C for 24 hours. After this the 14 extracts of Passiflora were solubilized in dimethyl 163 sulfoxide (DMSO, 0.7%), and added to each well at the concentration of 50 µg/mL. The cells 164 were then incubated for 72 h at 37°C in a 5% CO 2 atmosphere. After 72 hours, MTT (0.5

FIGREF1.text: cycle analysis was performed to determine cell content, which reflects the cell 216 cycle phases (G0/G1, S, and G2/M). For this, HL-60 cells were plated in 24-well plates at the 217 concentration of 0.3 x 10 6 cells/mL and incubated for 72 h with P. alata leaf extract (9.69, 218 19.77 and 38.74 μg/mL). Doxorubicin (0.3 μg/mL) was used as a positive control. After the 219 incubation period an aliquot of the cell suspension (50 μL) was transferred to an Eppendorff 220 tube and incubated for another 30 minutes with 100 μL of a lysis solution containing propidium 37°C (24). The samples were then analyzed in the program Guava Express Plus, where the 223 number of cells in each phase of the cell cycle was obtained along with the number are presented with mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM), standard deviation 228 (SD), or IC 50 values; confidence intervals (CI 95%) were obtained by nonlinear regression. 229 Differences among the experimental groups were compared by one-way variance analysis 230 (ANOVA), followed by Newman-Keuls test (p < 0.05). All analyses were carried out using the 231 Graphpad program (Intuitive Software for Science, San Diego, CA, USA). 232 233 Results and Discussion 234 Based on the fact that some species of the genus Passiflora have cytotoxic activity 235 against tumor cell lines and that relatively few species have been evaluated for their possible 236 anticancer activity, we selected 14 species of Passiflora cultivated in Brazil, produced by ASE 237 method to evaluate their potential in vitro cytotoxic activity. 238 The cell growth inhibition percentage (GI%) of the Passiflora extracts was evaluated 239 against three human cancer cell lines (HCT-116, OVACAR-8, and SF-295) in a single 240 concentration of 50 µg/mL and measured by MTT assay after 72 hours of incubation

FIGREF2.text: For a natural compound to progress as a potential anticancer drug candidate, it is 290 necessary to determine the degree of specificity of the drug by evaluating in vitro cytotoxic 291 activity against non-tumor cells (26,27). For this, ELPA was subjected to in vitro cytotoxic 292 activity evaluation against non-tumor cells (PBMC); the results demonstrated that the 293 compound shows no cytotoxic activity against PBMC

FIGREF4.text: Passiflora spp. are usually C-glycosylated with one or more sugar 305 units. Different fragmentation patterns were observed in MS/MS experiments for flavone C-The observed cytotoxic activity of ELPA demonstrated in this study might be attributed 348 to the mixture of various flavonoids found in the extract. Flavonoids have the potential to 349 modify many biological cancer events, such as apoptosis, vascularization, cell differentiation 350 and proliferation (34). Flavonoids found in ELPA such as vitexin and isovitexin also exert 351 chemotherapeutic potential against breast, hepatic, colorectal, lung, skin, oral, prostate, cervix, 352 ovary, esophagus and leukemic cancers (35). Orientin shows an inhibitory effect on the 353 proliferation of esophageal cancer cells (EC-109) and isoorientin demonstrated the ability to 354 inhibit proliferation of liver cancer cells (HepG2) (36-38). Diosmetin, found in ELPA 355 conjugated with C-glucosyl groups (8-C-Glucosyldiosmetin and 6-C-Glucosyldiosmetin), is 356 described as having in vitro anticancer activity against several tumor cells lines, with potent 357 inhibition against leukemic cells (P-388), and lesser cytotoxic activity against HepG2, Hep3B, 358 MDA-MB-231, MCF-7, A549, and Ca9-22 tumor cells (39). These data may justify the in vitro 359 cytotoxic effect presented by ELPA. 360 For drug discovery, cell death related testing is paramount in oncology because 361 resistance to dying is a hallmark of cancer cells (40). Knowing the cytotoxic activity 362 demonstrated by ELPA, we decided to identify the mechanism of the cytotoxicity induced by 363 the extract. For this, HL-60 neoplastic cells were selected for subsequent testing based on the 364 fact that the lineage is among the most widely used cellular models of myeloid origin, and 365 simultaneously was the lineage against which ELPA demonstrated its highest cytotoxic 366 potency. Three concentrations of ELPA, ½ IC 50 (9.69 μg/mL), IC 50 (19.37 μg/mL) and 2 × IC 50 367 (38.74 μg/mL) were chosen. 368 To ascertain the cellular death process in cancer cells, two tests were performed, 369 hematoxylin-eosin coloration analyzed by light microscopy, and ethidium bromide/acridine 370 orange coloration using fluorescence microscopy. After 72 h incubation, the effect of ELPA 371 was evaluated based on cell morphology using hematoxylin-eosin. The HL-60 cells treated Photomicrography of human tumor cells (HL-60) submitted to hematoxylin/eosin 378 differential staining after 72 hours of incubation and analyzed under a light microscope (100X). 379 A -negative control, B -cells treated with ELPA 9.69 µg/mL, C -cells treated with ELPA 380 19.77 µg/mL, D -cells treated with ELPA 38,74 µg/mL and E -cells treated with doxorubicin. 381 Black arrows indicate cell volume reduction and nuclear fragmentation; red arrows indicate 382 loss of membrane integrity, green arrows indicate cells in mitosis and orange arrow cell 383 swelling. 384 385 To confirm the light microscopy findings, we performed a morphological analysis of 386 cells treated with ELPA by staining and examining cells with AO/EB by fluorescence 387 microscopy. The percentages of viable, apoptotic and necrotic cells were calculated. After 72 388 h, HL-60 cells treated with ELPA showed a reduction in the percentage of viable cells for the 389 concentrations of 9.69 µg/mL (48.82 ± 3.76%), 19.77 µg/mL (41.88 ± 2.58%) and 38.74 µg/mL 390 (34.74 ± 1.25%) when compared to the NC group (91.67 ± 1.72%). The percentage of cells in 391 apoptosis increased for the concentrations of 9.69 µg/mL (30.74 ± 3.22%), 19.77 µg/mL (32.44 392 ± 3.23%) and 38.74 µg/mL (35.88 ± 3.06%) when compared to the NC group (4.95 ± 0.98%). 393 Another process of cell death observed was the increase in the percentage of cells in necrosis, data reaffirm the results found in the morphological analyses using light 398 microscopy; demonstrating that ELPA can cause cell death by apoptotic and necrotic 399 processes. Apoptosis is a programmed cell death process, and many studies suggest the 400 activation of apoptosis as one of the most effective forms of chemotherapy to prevent the 401 development and progression of cancer (41,42). Photodynamic treatment and certain 402 antineoplastic agents, such as β-lapachone and DNA alkylating agents induce cell death by 403 apoptosis and simultaneously induce cell death by necrosis in a variety of cancer cells (43,44). 404 Considering the two cell death processes involved, ELPA is a promising candidate for in vivo 405 evaluation in animal experimental tumor models. ELPA (µg/mL) The morphological analysis in HL-60 indicated that apoptosis is one of the mechanisms 417 of death involved in the cytotoxicity observed in ELPA, we resolved to determine DNA 418 fragmentation and alteration in the cell cycle through flow cytometry. The results concerning 419 cell cycle progression showed that the ELPA at all concentrations tested showed a significant 420 increase in the percentage of cells in the G2/M phase, being indicative of cell cycle arrest in 421 the specific phase (

FIGREF8.text: Photomicrography of human tumor cells (HL-60) submitted to hematoxylin/eosin differential staining after 72 hours of incubation and analyzed under a light microscope (100X). A -negative control, B -cells treated with ELPA 9.69 µg/mL, C -cells treated with ELPA 19.77 µg/mL, D -cells treated with ELPA 38,74 µg/mL and E -cells treated with doxorubicin. Black arrows indicate cell volume reduction and nuclear fragmentation; red arrows indicate loss of membrane integrity, green arrows indicate cells in mitosis and orange arrow cell swelling.

FIGREF9.text: Identification of the type of cell death induced by P. alata leaf extract (EFPA) against HL-60. Viable cells (white bar), apoptosis (gray bar) and necrosis (black bar) were determined by fluorescence microscopy using ethidium bromide/acridine orange after 72 hours of incubation. The negative control (NC) was treated with DMSO 0.3%, and doxorubicin (Dox), used as a positive control. Data are presented as mean ± SEM of three independent experiments evaluated by one-way variance analysis (ANOVA) with a Student Newman Keuls post-test. *p < 0.05 compared to the NC group, and # p < 0.05 compared to the Dox group.

TABREF1.text: Cell growth inhibition percentage (GI%) of leaf extracts from 14 species of Passiflora 255 against human tumor cell lines. values are presented as the mean ± SD from three independent experiments measured using the MTT assay after 258 72 hours of incubation. All extracts were tested at a concentration of 50 μg/ml; Doxorubicin was used as the 259 positive control. 260261Although none of the three species highlighted in the present study had been previously262 evaluated for their cytotoxic activity against cancer cells, other species of the genus Passiflora 263 have been. The cytotoxic or antiproliferative activity of species of the genus Passiflora was 264 evidenced for the first time by Perry et al. (1991) (17) through study of P. tetandra leaf extract, . The ethanolic extract of P. 267 ligularis Juss. and the methanolic extract of the P. edullis fruit have been respectively described 268 as presenting activity against human hepatocellular carcinoma (Hep3B) and leukemic cell line 269 (CCRF-CEM) (11,12). Evaluation of the cytotoxic activity of P. alata leaf extract (ELPA) against tumor 283 and non-tumor cells. 284 Values were expressed as IC 50 and obtained by nonlinear regression from three independent experiments, 285 performed in triplicate and measured with the MTT assay after 72 h of incubation with the ELPA; values are 286 means with 95% confidence limits in parentheses. Doxorubicin was used as positive control.

TABREF2.text: Identification of the chemical constituents from ELPA by UHPLC-MS/MS.

TABREF3.text: Effect of P. alata leaf extract (ELPA) on nuclear DNA content in HL-60 cells 428 determined by flow cytometry. 429 The data presented correspond to the mean ± standard error of the mean of two independent experiments 430 performed in duplicate and evaluated by one-way analysis of variance with Student Newman Keuls post-test. *p 431 < 0.05 compared to the negative control. 432 433 Conclusions 434 In conclusion, we evaluated the cytotoxic potential of extracts from 14 Passiflora 435 species obtained by ASE. ELPA presented greater cytotoxic potential against tumor cells, 436 without cytotoxicity in non-tumor human cells. The in vitro cytotoxic activity may be a 437 consequence of synergistic action between the flavonoids found in ELPA, promoting cell cycle 438 arrest in the G2/M phase and inducing cell death by apoptosis and necrosis. This work thus 439 demonstrates the potential of Brazilian plants and opens perspectives for ELPA evaluation in 440 experimental in vivo tumor models. . CC-BY 4.0 International license author/funder.
